provenance: The artist's nephews, Benedetto and Cesare Gennari, Casa Gennari, Bologna; by descent to Carlo Gennari, Bologna (probably sold with large group of Guercino drawings to Forni); '[Francesco Forni, Bologna; sold to Bouverie]; John Bouverie, East Betchworth, Surrey (c.1745); his sister, Anne Bouverie, London (until 1757); her husband John Hervie (until 1764); his son, Christopher Hervey, East Betchworth, Surrey (until 1786); his aunt, Elizabeth Bouverie, Barham Court, Teston, Kent (until d. 1798; bequeathed to Middleton); Sir Charles Middleton, later 1st Baron Barham, Barham Court, Teston, Kent (until d. 1813); his son-in-law, Sir Gerard Noel Noel, 2nd Baron Barham (until d. 1838); his son Charles Noel, later 1st Earl of Gainsborough; by descent to Charles Noel, 3rd Earl of Gainsborough, Exton Park, Oakham, Rutlandshire, England (until '1922; 'his sale, London, Christie's, July 27, 1922). Sale, Vanderkindere, Brussels, June 12, 2012, no. 55, to Ongpin; [Stephen Ongpin, London, no. 9]
text:
The lion skin around Hercules’ shoulder and waist is a tour de force, drawn with long, seemingly formless pen strokes that artfully abstract and utterly enervate the once fierce Nemean lion. Marvel, too, at the sinuous contour lines defining Hercules’ tightly muscled abdomen and biceps. By contrast, Guercino described Hercules’ facial features and expression with short, tight strokes, producing a superb character study of roughened, hard-bitten, stubborn manliness. 

Guercino is among the most celebrated draftsmen of the 17th century. A successful painter, he kept his drawings largely to himself in his lifetime. They became prized works of collectors only after his death. He drew frequently, instinctively, and compulsively, using his quill pen to visualize, to think, to problem solve, to invent, and to have fun. This sheet, executed in pen and ink—his most natural medium of expression—embodies all the freedom, force, and finesse of his drawing style.
title: Hercules
